Yes, the IAEA has taken action against member states for non-compliance with nuclear safety standards in the past. The consequences for non-compliance vary depending on the severity of the violation and the cooperation of the member state. Here are a few examples:

1. South Korea: In 2012 and 2013, South Korea had several incidents where nuclear reactors were shut down due to unauthorized modifications, fuel rod problems, and other safety issues. As a result, the IAEA conducted a special inspection and found that South Korea lacked an effective safety culture. The IAEA then provided recommendations for improvements, and South Korea committed to implementing them.

2. Iran: In 2003, the IAEA discovered that Iran had not disclosed all of its nuclear activities and was in violation of its safeguards agreement. As a result, the IAEA started an investigation and imposed sanctions on Iran. In 2015, Iran agreed to limit its nuclear program in exchange for the lifting of sanctions.

3. Japan: In 2011, Japan had a nuclear disaster at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant following an earthquake and tsunami. The IAEA provided technical assistance and conducted a review of Japan's response to the disaster. The IAEA also made recommendations for improvements in nuclear safety and emergency preparedness.

Overall, the consequences for non-compliance with nuclear safety standards can range from recommendations for improvements to sanctions and international scrutiny. It is important for member states to take nuclear safety seriously and to work collaboratively with the IAEA to achieve the highest level of safety.
